instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
HI,
I have an  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has no power.

At first it pulled 19.9V from ampmetter, but no amp.
I notice that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was low and so I replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> = ISL95530HIZ-TR5664 for an <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> = ISL95530HIZ-TR5655 (not sure if compatible but I got none ISL95530HIZ-TR5664). For a while I geted the 8.7V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> but after a while it failed, and now only get 4.9V from ampmeter, and already replaced <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> but with the same result (4.9V).

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Maybe bad solders under <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Do you get 1V1 LDO for the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips?
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> comes on?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
HI,
I get 1.1V on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>, but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> only gets 2.8V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> has 5.2V on <CAPACITOR>C6900</CAPACITOR>. Is this ok?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
1V1 LDO appears only on the powered port.
If you can't get it on the other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip (when powered), there is a problem.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: But the 1534 only has one port...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Yeah, sorry...

Seems to have overload at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Can you check the board with thermal cam?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Yes, I can. shall I look for a shorted component on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Why?
You can't get there more than the voltage provided by charger.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> and R/<CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR> are good.
Compare diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with good board.

You should try another <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> has 9.9 ohm and <RESISTOR>R6994</RESISTOR> has 0.06 ohm. <CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR> seams to be ok, and the traces arte fine too.
I don't have other <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> to compare, and I already replaced 3 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> just to be sure, but the same result.
Can you give me a diode reference value of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>? On my board I get 0.383V
